G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This action is brought in the Hampden County Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, which vests the Superior Court with original jurisdiction over civil actions for damages in excess of $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 2, because the parties reside in Hampden County and the events giving rise to this action occurred there.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3(c).proposition: This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendant because he resides in Massachusetts and the tortious conduct alleged herein occurred within the Commonwealth. See G.L. c. 223A, § 3(c).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, landowners and those in control of property owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors and to neighboring persons foreseeably exposed to risks arising from conditions on the premises. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (imposing a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors); *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 743 (1995) (duty extends to foreseeable risks of harm).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85A.proposition: Plaintiff’s total damages for property loss, rental car expenses, loss of use, inconvenience, and other compensable harm are reasonably estimated to exceed the jurisdictional minimum for this Court. See G.L. c. 231, § 85A (burden of proof regarding property damage) and G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest on pecuniary damages in tort actions).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff’s total damages for property loss, rental car expenses, loss of use, inconvenience, and other compensable harm are reasonably estimated to exceed the jurisdictional minimum for this Court. See G.L. c. 231, § 85A (burden of proof regarding property damage) and G.L. c. 231, § 6B (prejudgment interest on pecuniary damages in tort actions).

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action, including filing fees and other taxable costs, pursuant to G.L. c. 261;

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, landowners and those in control of property owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors and to neighboring persons foreseeably exposed to risks arising from conditions on the premises. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (imposing a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors); *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 743 (1995) (duty extends to foreseeable risks of harm).
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolished the common‑law distinction between licensees and invitees and imposed a general duty of reasonable care owed by property occupiers to all lawful visitors. The quoted text is from a concurrence commenting on trespassers, but the majority at 363 Mass. 707 is widely cited for the rule that Massachusetts landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. However, Mounsey does not itself clearly extend that duty to ‘neighboring persons’ off the premises; that broader extension comes more from Davis v. Westwood Group and § 85 than from Mounsey. Thus, the case supports the proposition as to lawful visitors, but not fully as to neighboring persons.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: "We therefore hold that the common law distinction between invitees and licensees should be abolished, and that the occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors a duty to act as a reasonable man in all the circumstances." (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973)).

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, landowners and those in control of property owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors and to neighboring persons foreseeably exposed to risks arising from conditions on the premises. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973) (imposing a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors); *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739, 743 (1995) (duty extends to foreseeable risks of harm).
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that Massachusetts landowners/possessors owe a common-law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors and describes that duty, citing Mounsey and other premises-liability cases. It further recognizes a duty to exercise reasonable care in the use of land so as not to injure travelers on adjacent public highways, which aligns with the notion that the duty extends to neighboring persons foreseeably exposed to risks arising from conditions on the premises, even though the court ultimately finds no duty on these particular facts.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. … Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway.”

*Janosz v. J.C. Penney Co.*, 324 Mass. 3.proposition: A person who creates or maintains a condition on property that poses a foreseeable risk of harm has a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable injury or property damage to others. See *Janosz v. J.C. Penney Co.*, 324 Mass. 394, 396 (1949) (duty arises where harm is reasonably foreseeable); *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147–48 (2006) (duty includes reasonable steps to prevent harm from dangerous conditions under one’s control).

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.proposition: A person who creates or maintains a condition on property that poses a foreseeable risk of harm has a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable injury or property damage to others. See *Janosz v. J.C. Penney Co.*, 324 Mass. 394, 396 (1949) (duty arises where harm is reasonably foreseeable); *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147–48 (2006) (duty includes reasonable steps to prevent harm from dangerous conditions under one’s control).
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that a homeowner who allows guns to be stored on her property and permits unsupervised access by a person known to be violent and mentally unstable has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. The court grounds that duty in general tort principles of foreseeability and in the heightened care required for dangerous instrumentalities, including taking reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable criminal misuse of firearms stored on one’s premises. This aligns with the proposition that a person who creates or maintains a dangerous condition on property must exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm to others.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. This duty is owed to, inter alia, a law enforcement officer shot by the person granted unsupervised access, because the officer is a foreseeable victim of the alleged improper firearm storage.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff a duty, upon receiving actual notice of the dangerous condition and the foreseeable risk of the ladder falling onto Plaintiff’s car, to take reasonable measures to correct or mitigate that condition. See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 376–77 (2010) (duty of reasonable care to remedy or address known hazards); *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 154–55 (2013) (duty to take reasonable steps once a risk is known or reasonably should be known).
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: Papadopoulos expressly holds that property owners owe lawful visitors a general duty of reasonable care to remedy or address dangerous conditions on the property when the owner knows or reasonably should know of them, and it applies that principle specifically to hazards from snow and ice. While the facts concern a slip and fall rather than a falling object, the proposition cited—that a defendant with actual notice of a dangerous condition and foreseeable risk must take reasonable measures to correct or mitigate it—is directly consistent with the court’s articulation of the premises-liability duty in this case.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger. … Under this traditional premises liability standard, a fact finder will determine what snow and ice removal efforts are reasonable in light of the expense they impose on the landowner and the probability and seriousness of the foreseeable harm to others.” Papadopoulos, 457 Mass. at 383–84.

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.proposition: Defendant also owed Plaintiff a duty, upon receiving actual notice of the dangerous condition and the foreseeable risk of the ladder falling onto Plaintiff’s car, to take reasonable measures to correct or mitigate that condition. See *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 376–77 (2010) (duty of reasonable care to remedy or address known hazards); *Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 154–55 (2013) (duty to take reasonable steps once a risk is known or reasonably should be known).
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that a landowner is not relieved of a duty of reasonable care merely because a danger is open and obvious, and that once the defendant knows or has reason to know of the danger and that lawful entrants will nevertheless encounter it, the defendant has a duty to take reasonable steps to remedy or correct it. The court explains that, beyond any duty to warn, there remains a ‘duty to remedy’ an open and obvious condition when harm is reasonably anticipated, which fits the cited proposition that a defendant must take reasonable measures once a risk is known or should be known.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148, 1.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’… Section 343A thus instructs that although a duty to warn of an open and obvious danger would be superfluous… a landowner is not relieved from remedying that danger where he knows or has reason to know that lawful entrants may not heed the warning… On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”

*Koccora v. Horton*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 4.proposition: A reasonably prudent person in Defendant’s position, exercising ordinary care under the circumstances, would not have left a tall aluminum ladder standing unsecured in an area exposed to wind and in close proximity to vehicles and persons using the shared driveway. See *Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. at 147–49 (foreseeability of harm informs the scope of reasonable care); *Koccora v. Horton*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 441, 443–44 (1997) (negligence where defendant fails to secure object that foreseeably causes harm).
*Koccora v. Horton*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 4.case_name: Morton Buildings, Inc. v. Commissioner of Revenue
*Koccora v. Horton*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 4.support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts tax case about whether raw materials used to fabricate building components out-of-state are subject to the Massachusetts use tax. It does not address negligence, reasonable care, securing objects, foreseeability of physical harm, or any facts involving ladders, wind, vehicles, or personal injury. Citing Koccora v. Horton for a negligence principle about failing to secure an object is inaccurate; the case provides no support for that proposition.
*Koccora v. Horton*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 4.relevant_excerpt: Several principles that govern decision-making in tax cases warrant mention. The commissioner’s authority to tax must rest on an express statutory source. To the extent a taxing statute raises interpretive questions, doubts are to be resolved in favor of the taxpayer. … Broken down to its components, the use tax falls on tangible personal property that (1) is stored, used or otherwise consumed in the Commonwealth; (2) is purchased from any vendor; and (3) was purchased for storage, use, or consumption within the Commonwealth.

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of reasonable care required under Massachusetts common law negligence principles as reflected in the Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 302, 303, 307, which Massachusetts courts routinely rely upon in articulating the duty and breach elements. See, e.g., *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696–97 (2000) (citing Restatement in negligence analysis).
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.support_reasoning: The opinion does confirm that Massachusetts negligence law requires proof of duty, breach, loss, and causation and cites the Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281. However, it does not rely on or even mention Restatement §§ 302, 303, or 307, nor does it discuss how those sections articulate the duty or breach standard. The case is about failure of proof of causation, not about defining the standard of reasonable care using those specific Restatement sections, so it does not support the proposition as framed.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.”

*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co.*, 399 Mass..proposition: But for Defendant’s failure to secure or relocate the ladder, the ladder would not have toppled over onto Plaintiff’s car when the wind gust occurred. See *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co.*, 399 Mass. 790, 794–95 (1987) (causation satisfied where defendant’s negligence is a substantial contributing factor in the harm).
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co.*, 399 Mass..case_name: Solimene v. B. GRAUEL & CO., KG
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co.*, 399 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition is a specific but-for causation statement about a ladder and wind, and cites Solimene for the broader legal standard that causation is satisfied where defendant’s negligence is a substantial contributing factor. Solimene does discuss causation and uses the “substantial factor” formulation in the context of superseding cause and product design defects, but it does not involve or analyze a but-for causal chain like the ladder/wind scenario, nor does it articulate the precise rule stated in the parenthetical. The case therefore provides only general causation principles and not clear authority for the specific causation proposition as framed.
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co.*, 399 Mass..relevant_excerpt: Restatement (Second) of Torts, supra at § 440, defines superseding cause as “an act of a third person or other force which by its intervention prevents the actor from being liable for harm to another which his antecedent negligence is a substantial factor in bringing about.” … The plaintiff has the burden to show that Grauel’s negligence caused her injury. … The plaintiff sustained her burden by proving that there was a greater probability that the harm which occurred was due to causes for which Grauel was responsible.

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: Defendant’s conduct created a foreseeable risk that, during windy conditions, the ladder would be blown over and would strike Plaintiff’s vehicle parked or being maneuvered in the driveway. The occurrence of such harm was well within the scope of the risk created by Defendant’s negligence. See *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996) (foreseeable consequences of negligent conduct give rise to liability).
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The quoted concurring opinion states the opposite of what the proposition claims: it agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. The proposition uses Poskus to suggest that such harm was within the scope of foreseeable risk, but the case (at least as reflected here) concludes that the plaintiff’s injuries were not reasonably foreseeable, so it does not support the stated proposition.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

*Ford v. Flaherty*, 364 Mass. 382, 385\u.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages, together with statutory prejudgment interest from the date of commencement of the action pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, and taxable costs. See *Ford v. Flaherty*, 364 Mass. 382, 385–86 (1973) (prejudgment interest is mandatory in tort actions for pecuniary damages).
